Author: mroman
Content: I think that part of his point, which he has failed to articulate, is that future programmers need to undergo the inherent rigor of low level programming so as to build the mental muscle - so to speak - needed to solve highly complex  problems.\nI believe a suitable analogy is how Roman legionaries initially trained with lead swords.

Author: mtts
Content:
I personally don't see a desktop OS being "game changing" at this point anymore. We've pretty much figured out what we're going to be using desktop and laptop computers for by now.

But you're right in so far that Microsoft's all-important "legacy" stuff is by now so old it can easily be run in virtualization or even in emulation, so they're probably on the right track.

Author: michaelwolff
Content: great wish list, but amazed that there is nothing about work. here we are just about to enter a major global recession, and millions of people are going to be looking at different ways of getting work - for instance being able to find work anywhere in the global economy without having to move from their homes. but now there is a solution: see www.ki-work.com

Author: mtts
Content: The jump from OS 9 to OS X did not happen when Apple nearly went under. It happened after sales had picked up again with the release of the iMac and similar hardware. Of course Apple at the time was nowhere near as profitable as it is today, but saying it "nearly went under" is an exaggeration. That happened in the years before Jobs returned and in the first two years or so of his return.

Author: SwellJoe
Content:
But what did most of those guys actually accomplish? rtm and Shawn Fanning, we all know...but did Mitnick really do anything interesting other than get caught stealing phone service and equipment and given somewhat unfair treatment by the courts?

I got my first modem when I was 12 and grew up around that part of computer culture (and committed more than my share of federal crimes by the time of my 18th birthday), but as an adult I look back on the whole thing as rather embarrassing. If I'd only had access to real computers, I'm certain I wouldn't have found 2600 and the phreaking and cracking scene so interesting. And, of course, the really interesting stuff was happening on real computers.

Author: Maro
Content:
The point is, low-level, as the name implies, is at a lower level than high-level. So every once in a while, you'll run into problems at the higher levels, and you have to dig into lower level stuff to solve a problem.

So what do you do if you cannot because you have no conception about the lower-levels / overall architecture? I've seen PHP programmers run into bugs and throw up their hands and yell "It just doesn't work! But the bug cannot be in my code!". Of course the bug was in their code, they just have no deep understanding of even their own environment.
